child.pub-comments: Distant genetic proposals would have Klamath as part of Plateau Penutian... the evidence for a genetic relationship between Klamath, Sahaptian, and Molala is more credible.

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 4: Languages of North America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America, 107-155. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271

Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 4: Languages of North America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America, 107-155. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271
child.pub-comments: It has long been conjectured that Beothuk may be related to the Algonquian family, but the material available on the language is so scant and poorly recorded that evaluation of the proposed connection is difficult.

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 4: Languages of North America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America, 107-155. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271
child.pub-comments: Esselen has usually been placed with Hokan, but the data are so fragmentary as to defy classification.

child.pub-comments: The often assumed classification of Siuslaw as Penutian is not at present substantiated.

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 4: Languages of North America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America, 107-155. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271
child.pub-comments: Berman has shown that it is highly likely that Molala is related to Klamath and Sahaptian.

child.pub-comments: May be a hybrid/creolization of Eyak-Athabaskan and some unrelated language.

child.pub-comments: Opinion differs whether these two main dialects constitute distinct languages or are only divergent dialects of a single language. For now it is best to consider the genetic affiliation of Haida unknown.

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 4: Languages of North America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America, 107-155. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271
child.pub-comments: Proposals of distant genetic relationships have frequently placed Karankawa with the so-called Coahuiltecan languages; this hypothesis does not hold up.

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 4: Languages of North America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America, 107-155. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271
child.alt-names: Jaranames, Hanama, Haname, Chaimame, Charinames, Xaranames, Taranames
child.pub-comments: Aranama is known only from a two-word phrase given to Gatschet in 1884 by a Tonkawa speaker.

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle. 1997. Chapter 4: Languages of North America. In Lyle Campbell, American Indian Languages: The Historical Linguistics of Native America, 107-155. Oxford: Oxford University Press. ISBN 0195094271
